awd_titl_txt: The Development and Socialization of Anger in Young Infants
awd_abstract_narration: Anger is a basic human emotion which typically occurs when                      control of outcomes is lost or goals are thwarted.  Anger                       expressions are observed even in 2- to 8- month old infants in                  such contexts.  Yet, individual differences in the pattern of                   anger/frustration are seen.  Some infants show only anger when                  control of an expected event is disrupted, others show a mixture                of anger and sad expressions, while still others show only                      sadness.  The project will examine empirically two aspects of the               early anger response.  First, the project will study the                        conditions  under which loss of control of outcomes elicits anger               early in life.  Of particular interest is how the anger response                may vary when loss of control is only partial.   Secondly, the                  project will explore the relation of early parental                             responsiveness and temperament factors to individual differences                in infant anger expression.  Thus, the research will establish                  the basic dynamics of early anger in response to frustrating                    events, including its origins in socialization and constitutional               factors.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences
